response.answer_text: [math]35x^2 - 12x + 1 - (6x - 1)(x + 3)[/math] [math]35x^2 - 12x + 1 - (6x^2 - 17x + 3)[/math] [math]35x^2 - 12x + 1 - 6x^2 + 17x - 3[/math] [math]35x^2 - 6x^2 - 12x + 17x + 1 - 3[/math] [math]29x^2 + 5x - 2[/math] You could reduce the quadratic equation by factoring the first co-efficient [math]29(x2 + 0.172414x - 0.068966)[/math] Find the discriminant of the remaining quadratic equation to see how many roots you can obtain from it in order to  factor it [math]0.172414^2 - [(4)(1)(-0.068966)] = 0.305591[/math] That the discriminant is [math]0.305591 [/math]means that you will be expecting two distinct roots from the  remaining quadratic equation. So find the roots. [math][0.172414 / [(2)(1)]] - [SQRT(0.305591) / [(2)(1)]][/math][math] = -0.190194[/math] [math][0.172414 / [(2)(1)]] + [SQRT(0.305591) / [(2)(1)]] = 0.362617[/math] With your two newly found roots; you now have the following: [math]29(x - 0.190194)(x + 0.362617)[/math] Good luck
[math]35x^2-12x+1-(6x-1)(x+3)[/math] Expand the brackets, [math]35x^2-12x+1-6x^2-18x+x+3[/math] [math]29x^2-29x+4[/math] [math](29x-2)(x-2)+31x[/math] Thanks for the A2A
